hints_html: Recall that if there are n loops and m current sources then we have n+m unknowns.
hints_latex:
Recall that if there are n loops and m current sources then we have n+m
unknowns.
hints_raw: Recall that if there are n loops and m current sources then we have n+m unknowns.
question: A 09
sols_html:
From the current loop rule we know that each loop gets its own current which is an unknown for the system. We also need an unknown for the voltage drop that occurs across each current source. Since we have three loops we have 3 loop currents, \(i_1,i_2,i_3\) and we have one current source so we have 1 unknown voltage drop \(v_1\) for current source E. Therefore in total we have 4 unknowns for our linear system,

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} i_1\\ i_2\\ i_3\\ v_1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
From the current loop rule we know that each loop gets its own current
which is an unknown for the system. We also need an unknown for the
voltage drop that occurs across each current source. Since we have three
loops we have \textbf{3} loop currents, $i_1,i_2,i_3$ and we have one
current source so we have \textbf{1} unknown voltage drop $v_1$ for
current source E. Therefore in total we have \textbf{4} unknowns for our
linear system,

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}
i_1\\
i_2\\
i_3\\
v_1
\end{bmatrix}.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
From the current loop rule we know that each loop gets its own current which is an unknown for the system.  We also need an unknown for the voltage drop that occurs across each current source.  Since we have three loops we have '''3''' loop currents, <math>i_1,i_2,i_3</math> and we have one current source so we have '''1''' unknown voltage drop <math>v_1</math> for current source E.  Therefore in total we have '''4''' unknowns for our linear system,

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
i_1\\
i_2\\
i_3\\
v_1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>.
